titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Davison Fund, Inc. records (II) FA080
titlestmt.author: S.W.G.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-09-15 00:01:47 -0400.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Davison Fund, Inc. was established by John D. Rockefeller, Jr. in 1934, having in mind the charitable undertakings which had formerly received his personal consideration. The establishment contained no instruction as to beneficiaries, nor any limitation as to field. The beneficiaries selected by the Fund were regarded as a means to an end, the effective application of resources for charitable purposes. In general, the program developed from two motivations: an interest in the social, cultural, educational, and health aspects of the citizens of New York City and its environs (including Westchester County); and "the recognition of the outstanding importance and wide significance of certain problems which cut across national and international boundaries and which invite the cooperation and support of thoughtful men everywhere."

In view of the first motivation, social work was the dominant interest of the Fund, including child welfare, medicine and health, relief of distress, and the improvement of social conditions. It also aimed to succor the indigent and to improve the standards of agencies actively at work in this field. The second motivation found its voice most notably in religion and to a lesser extent in "projects soundly conceived for the benefit of the Negro either in the field of direct social service or through those media which seek to improve relationships between the races."

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The records are arranged in three series:

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Davison Fund II records, the records of the Davison Fund itself, were given to the Rockefeller Archive Center by the Rockefeller family.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: See also the Davison Fund, Inc. (I) Collection. Many of the records in the DF I collection are also in the DF II collection. However, financial materials, including ledgers, journals, and trial balances, appear only in the DF I collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains correspondence, dockets, financial reports, minutes, and manuals relating to the Davison Fund, Inc.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use." If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the user's responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged alphabetically by the type of material, and thereunder chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series 1, Administration, includes minutes and dockets of the Board of Trustees, the Committee on Religious Projects, the Executive Committee, and the Special Appropriations Committee. Also included in this series are documents of record, financial reports, and the Policy Manual of 1938.

odd.head: General
odd.p: The Davison Fund index provides indexing to correspondence, appropriations, declinations, and minutes. The index includes entries for personal names and organizations, but not subjects or places.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The index is arranged in 4 series of index cards: Correspondence, Appropriations, Declinations, and Minutes. Each series is arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Provides indexing to correspondence found in the Davison Funds's Series 2: Appropriations files.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Cards include headings for organizations, but are otherwise blank.
